bioghist.p: The Burd family was a prominent Pennsylvania family active in the social, economic and political affairs of the state. Col. James Burd (1726-1793) was born in Scotland and immigrated to the United States, settling in Lancaster County with his wife Sarah Shippen, a member of the prominent Shippen family of Lancaster and Shippensburg. Edward Shippen Burd (1779-1848) was the grandson of James and Sarah Burd. He was a lawyer in Philadelphia, married to Eliza Howard Simms, daughter of Woodrop and Sarah Sims. Edward Shippen and Eliza Burd's children included Elizabeth (1815-1845/6), Margaret (1819-1844), and Wooddrop (1822-1837), all of whom predeceased both of their parents. Edward Shippen Burd died in 1848; Eliza Burd honored her husband by commissioning the erection of a monument to him at St. Stephen's Church, and several years later conceived the idea of establishing a school for fatherless girls. She died in 1860, but her will provided for the principles and funding of this institution.

scopecontent.p: This is a collection of Burd family papers. Materials include: letters from Joseph Shippen to Edward Shippen Burd, 1798-1805; a letter from James Burd to Edward Shippen, 1757; two volumes containing copies of the will of Edward Shippen Burd; several deeds, dating from 1813 to 1833. Books belonging to Margaret C. Burd, Elizabeth Shippen Burd, Eliza Howard (Sims) Burd, Woodropp Sims Burd, and Sarah Hopkins. These include commonplace books of poetry and watercolor illustrations; scrapbooks of illustrations; books with addresses of friends in Paris and Philadelphia; volumes of poetry; a copy book; and a volume of manuscript sheet music. A box of calling cards of Mme E.S. Burd, Mlle Burd, and Mlle M.C. Burd. (mother and two daughters). A 1932 newspaper clipping about Elizabeth Shippen Burd. The collection also includes interior and exterior photographs of the Burd School at 63rd and Market Street and photographs of a church.

accessrestrict.p: The collection is open for research.
